page.title: 14Lydney Park
page.content: Lydney Park, the home of Viscount Bledisloe, covers a large area of woods and fields on the western edge of Lydney. It is open to the public on certain days and contains a deer park in which visitors may picnic. Many people go to see the beautiful gardens, particularly the displays of rhododendrons and azaleas in Spring. By about 300 AD the Romans had built a Hospitium and Bath-house in the camp there and a Temple to the local god Nodens was added in 364 AD. This is one of the most important Roman discoveries in Britain. One of the boys in my class at school found some Roman coins near there. He handed them over to be kept in the small museum at the Park which also contains other relics found during excavations at the camp.
